page.title: Main page - choose lesson part
page.contents:
You do not have to finish the whole lesson in one sitting.  You may retry the lesson if you are not happy with the outcome.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  I am including this so that you can check whether you have completed all parts.  Note in particular that for some reason the moodle lessons sometimes skip the reflective writing items (I haven't figured out why), so this map helps you figure out where those should be:

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

page.title: Which has more energy (springs)
page.contents:
Let’s think about a spring.

  • In situation A the spring is relaxed (i.e. neither stretched, nor compressed).
  • In situation B the same spring is compressed (i.e. its length is less than its equilibrium length).
  • The spring is stationary in both situations.

Does this spring have more energy in situation A or in situation B?

answer.answer_text: It has more energy in situation B.
answer.response: Yup.  A compressed spring has more  capacity to change itself and other things than a relaxed one does.

answer.answer_text: It has more energy in situation A.
answer.response: If you leave the relaxed spring alone it will just sit there doing nothing.  It has little or no "capacity to cause change" to anything.  What happens to a compressed spring if you let it go?  Does it just sit there doing nothing?

answer.answer_text: It has the same energy in both situations.
answer.response: If you leave the relaxed spring alone it will just sit there doing nothing.  It has little or no "capacity to cause change" to anything.  What happens to a compressed spring if you let it go?  Does it just sit there doing nothing?

answer.answer_text: We don’t have enough information.
answer.response: If you leave the relaxed spring alone it will just sit there doing nothing.  It has little or no "capacity to cause change" to anything.  What happens to a compressed spring if you let it go?  Does it just sit there doing nothing?

page.title: Unproductive pushing on a box
page.contents: You push on a heavy box.  You exert a 400 N force on the box for 2 s.  The box is very heavy and the floor is rough so the box does not move.  How much work have you done on the box?

answer.answer_text: None.
answer.response: Correct. Work is only done when a force acts on an object while the object moves.

answer.answer_text: 800 Ns
answer.response: First of all, that is an impulse, not work (we haven't even learned how to calculate work yet, which should be a hint to you). Second of all, work is only done when a force acts on a moving object.
No, work is only done when a force acts on a moving object.
No, work is only done when a force acts on a moving object. Besides, we haven't even learned how to calculate work yet, which should be a hint to you.
No, work is only done when a force acts on a moving object. Besides, we haven't even learned how to calculate work yet, which should be a hint to you.

page.title: ball dropped from rest - choose energy bar chart
page.contents:
A ball is dropped from rest as shown.

Which of the following is the most correct energy bar chart representing this situation?

answer.answer_text: B
answer.response: Yes. It starts with lots of gravitational potential energy and ends with lots of kinetic energy. The total energy remains constant.

answer.answer_text: A
answer.response:
No. There are several things wrong with A. 1. It shows the ball starting with lots of kinetic energy and ending up with no kinetic energy, but having gained some gravitational potential energy. But the ball started at rest (K=0) and went down (so it lost gravitational potential energy).
2. The total energy should be constant. So the initial should equal the final.
3. The initial total energy bar is wrong because it should be the same height as the initial kinetic energy. In other words, it doesn't actually show a total.

answer.answer_text: C
answer.response: No. The ball starts at rest so the initial kinetic energy should be zero.

answer.answer_text: D
answer.response: No. The total energy should be constant. So the initial and final bars should all be the same height.

page.title: End of cluster 9-1
page.contents: End of cluster

page.title: Ball dropped from rest
page.contents: Suppose that a ball is dropped from rest.  At the initial time the ball is at some height and has just been released, so it is stationary.  At the final time the ball has fallen some distance and is moving.  The system is the ball and the Earth.  Which is the most correct energy bar chart for this situation?

answer.response: Yes.  U_G decreases.  K starts  at zero and increases.
No.  The ball is changing speed.  So the kinetic energy of the system must change.
No.  The ball is  initially stationary, so its  kinetic energy must be zero at that moment.
No.  The ball moves down.  So U_G must decrease.

page.title: Energy transfer for ball going upwards
page.contents: You throw a ball upwards.  As it goes up what happens to its energy?

answer.answer_text: Its kinetic energy is transformed to gravitational potential energy.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: Its energy decreases since it slows down.
answer.response: No. Energy doesn't just disappear.

answer.answer_text: Its energy increases since it is going higher.
answer.response: No energy doesn't just get "created".

answer.answer_text: Its gravitational potential energy is transformed into kinetic energy.
answer.response: No. It is going up (so its gravitational potential energy is increasing) and it slows down as it goes up (so its kinetic energy decreases).

page.title: rock falling
page.contents: You drop a rock off of a cliff.  What happens to the energy of the rock?

answer.answer_text: The rock's gravitational potential energy is transformed to kinetic energy.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: The rock is speeding up, so its energy is increasing.
answer.response: No. Energy doesn't just get "created".

answer.answer_text: It is going down so its energy is decreasing.
answer.response: No, energy doesn't just "disappear".

answer.answer_text: Its kinetic energy is being transformed into gravitational potential energy.
answer.response: No. It is going down so its gravitational potential energy is decreasing. It is speeding up so its kinetic energy is increasing.

page.title: mass on spring - greatest K
page.contents: A mass on a frictionless surface is vibrating back and forth (horizontally) on the end of a spring. When does the mass and spring system have the largest kinetic energy?

answer.answer_text: When the mass is passing through the equilibrium position.
answer.response: Yes, that is when it has no spring potential energy so it has maximum kinetic energy at that moment.

answer.answer_text: When the spring is either fully compressed or fully stretched.
answer.response: No. That is when it has the most spring potential energy, so it has no kinetic energy at those moments.

answer.answer_text: The energy is conserved so the mass and spring always have the same potential energy.
answer.response: No. The energy is conserved. But its energy is being transformed back and forth between spring potential energy and kinetic energy.

answer.answer_text: When the force exerted by the spring is a maximum.
answer.response: No, maximum spring force occurs at maximum displacement. That is when the spring potential energy is a maximum, so it is when the kinetic energy is zero.

answer.answer_text: There is no vertical motion so the potential energy is not changing.
answer.response: You are thinking about gravitational potential energy. It is true that the gravitational potential energy isn't changing, but the spring potential energy is changing.

page.title: mass on spring - greatest U
page.contents: A mass on a frictionless surface is vibrating back and forth (horizontally) on the end of a spring. When does the mass and spring system have the largest potential energy?

answer.answer_text: When the spring is either fully compressed or fully stretched.
answer.response: Yes, that's when the displacement from equilibrium is largest so it is when the mass and spring has the most spring potential energy.

answer.answer_text: When the mass is passing through the equilibrium position.
answer.response: No. That is when its spring potential energy is zero. It has maximum kinetic energy at those times.

answer.answer_text: The energy is conserved so the mass and spring always have the same potential energy.
answer.response: No. It is true that the energy is conserved. But it is being transformed back and forth between kinetic and spring potential energy.

answer.answer_text: When the mass is moving at maximum speed.
answer.response: No. That is when the mass has the largest kinetic energy.

answer.answer_text: There is no vertical motion so the potential energy is not changing.
answer.response: No. You must be thinking about gravitational potential energy. The system's gravitational potential energy isn't changing, but its spring potential energy is changing.

page.contents: Cluster

page.title: definition of elastic collision
page.contents: What is a perfectly elastic collision?

answer.answer_text: A collision in which mechanical energy is conserved.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: A collision in which mechanical energy is lost.
answer.response: No. That is an inelastic collision.

answer.answer_text: A collision in which momentum is conserved.
answer.response: No. That's the definition of an isolated collision.

answer.answer_text: A collision in which the colliding objects stick together.
answer.response: No, that is a completely inelastic collision. It results in the maximum loss of mechanical energy, so this is the opposite of a perfectly elastic collision.

page.title: what quantities are conserved in collisions
page.contents: Which of the following is a correct statement about what quantities are conserved in collisions?

answer.answer_text: Momentum is conserved in all isolated collisions. Mechanical energy is conserved in perfectly elastic collisions.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: Colliding objects' momentum and energy are always conserved.
answer.response: No. The energy and momentum of the universe are always conserved. But any given pair of colliding objects could be exchanging momentum and energy with their environment.

answer.answer_text: Momentum is always conserved. Energy is only conserved in perfectly elastic collisions.
answer.response: No. The momentum is only conserved in an isolated system.

answer.answer_text: Momentum is conserved in all isolated collisions. Mechanical energy is conserved in completely inelastic collisions.
answer.response: No. Completely inelastic collisions have maximum energy loss. So energy is not conserved in them.

answer.answer_text: Momentum is always conserved. Energy is only conserved in completely inelastic collisions.
answer.response: No. Momentum is only conserved in isolated systems. Completely inelastic collisions have maximum energy loss, so energy is not conserved in them.

page.title: Applying the brakes
page.contents: You are riding your bike on a flat bit or road when you apply the brakes and stop. What has happened to the kinetic energy that you and the bike had before you applied the brakes?

answer.answer_text: It has been transformed to thermal energy.
answer.response: Yes, there was a lot of friction in the action of the brakes. So mechanical energy has been transformed into thermal energy.

answer.answer_text: It was conserved because energy is always conserved.
answer.response: Energy is always conserved but individual types of energy are not. You have stopped so your kinetic energy has definitely "disappeared". It hasn't really "disappeared", though. It must have been transformed into another form of energy.

answer.answer_text: It was transformed into gravitational potential energy.
answer.response: No. You aren't going up or down. There are no transformations to or from gravitational potential energy going on here.

answer.answer_text: It flowed away into the ground.
answer.response: No. Energy doesn't really "flow". It isn't a liquid that moves around. Objects "have" energy and that energy can be transformed into different forms.

answer.answer_text: It was transformed into spring potential energy.
answer.response: Nope. There are no springs or other deformable "springy" objects here.

answer.answer_text: It kept going and left you behind.
answer.response: No. Energy isn't a physical object. It doesn't "go" anywhere. Objects have energy. So your energy can't "keep going without you". It has to have turned into some other form of energy.

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------After Lecture 3-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1101 - Response to Unit 9 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "Lectures 1-3".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. In your own words, give a definition of the "state of a system".

You will add more to this sheet after some of the other lectures in this unit.


------------After Lecture 5-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after watching Lecture 3.  If you don't already have that (perhaps because you are watching the videos out of sequence) then go back to Lecture 3, watch it, answer the questions and then start your writing.  Then come back to this page.

Under what you wrote for Lecture 3 write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. Make up 2 examples of situations in which one type of energy is converted to another type.  For each example, clearly define the system and explain what energy transformation takes place.

You will scan this sheet, along with an addition to your cheat sheet, and submit it on moodle under the Written Response for this lesson.

page.title: Bumping into spring
page.contents: Springs of various sorts are often used to "cushion" impacts to prevent damage to various objects.  In a factory a heavy cart full of boxes to be shipped is rolling along a horizontal track.  At the end of the track is a big spring which brings the cart gently to rest.  As the cart runs into the spring and compresses it what is the main energy transformation that is taking place?

answer.answer_text: K -> U<sub>s</sub>
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: K -> E<sub>therm</sub>
answer.response: A bit of this is probably happening but it is not the main energy transformation taking place. What kind of energy results from compressing a spring?

answer.answer_text: U<sub>g</sub> -> U<sub>s</sub>
answer.response: No. The track is horizontal. Nothing is moving up or down so no gravitational potential energy is being gained or lost.

answer.answer_text: E<sub>therm</sub> -> U<sub>s</sub>
answer.response: Do you expect boxes to spontaneously cool down and start moving across the floor? Thermal energy does not normally get transformed into mechanical energy.

answer.answer_text: U<sub>s</sub> -> K
answer.response: No, this is backwards. The cart is coming to rest (losing kinetic energy) and compressing a spring (gaining spring potential energy).

page.title: Air puck on spring, released
page.contents:
Consider an air puck on the end of a spring.  The spring is horizontal as shown.  The air puck starts stationary and the spring is initially compressed.  The air puck is then released and the force by the spring accelerates it.  A short time later the air puck is moving and the spring is relaxed.

Let the system be the air puck and the spring.  Did the system’s K increase or decrease?  Did the system’s UG increase or decrease?

answer.answer_text: K increased.  UG was unchanged.
answer.response: Yes.  It speeds up so  K increases.  Nothing changes height, so  UG is unchanged.

answer.answer_text: K increased.  UG decreased.
answer.response: UG changes when things move up or down.  Did anything  move  up or down here?

answer.answer_text: K and UG both increased.
answer.response: UG changes when things move up or down.  Did anything  move  up or down here?

answer.answer_text: K and UG both decreased.
answer.response:
Things that are moving faster have more K than things that are not moving.

UG changes when things move up or down.  Did anything  move  up or down here?

answer.answer_text: K and UG both stayed the same.
answer.response: No.  K depends on the speed of things.  The air puck is moving faster at the end than it was at the beginning.

page.title: Repeat with different axes
page.contents: Suppose the situation is exactly the same as what we just saw (ball thrown at some angle  off  the top of a cliff.  We want to know speed at the moment of impact with the ground), but we define our axes to be at ground level.  The system is the ball and the Earth.  Which is the most correct energy bar chart in this case?

answer.response: Yes.  U_G starts positive and is zero at the end.  K increases.
No.  The ball must be going  faster at the end than it was at the beginning, so K must increase.
No.  This was the correct bar chart when the axes were at the initial location of the ball so that y_i = 0.  But now the axes are at the bottom of the cliff so y_i is not zero.

No.  There are two problems with this one.  First of  all, the ball ends at the same height as the axes (y = 0).  So  the final U_G must be zero.  Also, the ball was moving at the start, so K_i can't be zero.
